awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Triassic-Jurassic Fossils and the Origins of the Crocodilian Skull
awd_abstract_narration:
Crocodilians and their closest relatives have an exceptional fossil record from the last 250 million years, documenting the origins of their many specializations. Here the PIs investigate for the first time the origins of the unique jaw-closing system that allows crocodilians to have the strongest bite force of any vertebrate, using biomechanical analyses integrated with a study of their evolutionary relationships. The PIs will also study how the size of air spaces in the skull relates to a dramatic increase in global temperatures and decrease in atmospheric oxygen at the end of the Triassic Period. The study seeks to determine whether the origin of features increasing bite force were related to the increase in air spaces in the skull, or whether these two signature adaptations of modern crocodilians evolved independently.
 
Crocodilians are charismatic animals that lend themselves well to educational outreach, and this project will utilize the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History's Q'rius learning center and University of Missouri's Inside Dinosaurs program as platforms to contribute to public scientific literacy and public engagement with science. The PIs and their students will engage in public presentations and develop interactive experiences based on 3D skulls printed from project CT scans. Collaboration with researchers in China will strengthen international collaboration.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Having lived alongside crocodilians since our origins, alligators, crocodiles and their relatives continue to capture our imaginations and attention. Despite everyone on the planet having a sense of what crocodilians look like and how they behave, numerous features evolved by crocodilians remain unknown. In particular we know little about how their characteristically flat heads are capable of creating such violent and forceful feeding behaviors and when these features evolved during the natural history of the lineage. Here we developed and used a number of new imaging and mathematical tools to learn how crocs evolved their flat heads from tall-skulled ancestors and how their jaw muscles changed to create their powerful biting behaviors. We scanned and built 3D models of numerous living and fossil crocodilians and croc-ancestors including several key fossil species from the Triassic and Jurassic periods as well as historical living specimens housed in the country’s major museums. We developed new ways of seeing and measuring jaw muscles and nerves in 3D. We learned that as croc skulls got flat, their muscles became suboptimal for biting and they had to increase muscle mass to keep up with high bite forces. We learned that jaw joints of crocs have shapes that reflect the forces these muscles transmit through the skull and that we can now estimate behaviors of even fragmentary remains of crocodilian skulls. Together these findings show that crocs are not some living fossil but instead remain a constantly evolving and diverse clade of animals.

This work helped create numerous new 3D models of skulls that can be 3D printed, viewed using virtual reality equipment or used for additional research, engineering studies, paleontology, comparative anatomy and educational programs. We have used much of this material to conduct outreach programs in the Mid-Missouri area including science cafes, school groups and science fairs reaching thousands of students and their families each year. We mobilized a number of 3D models to online, virtual anatomy sites where people around the world can explore the anatomy of alligators, crocodiles and their relatives. We organized scientific meetings and publications to bring researchers and the public together to better learn from the work.

The work here trained nearly a dozen undergraduates, 6 graduate students and a postdoc in new technological advances in imaging, 3D geometric and engineering approaches and mathematical analysis, as well as crocodilian and reptile natural history. We expect these results and tools to be applied to other fields of paleontology, biomechanics, engineering, and conservation biology. We anticipate our trainees from this project, the families and students we met along the way and others that discover this work will continue to share and build upon its successes into the future.   

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2022
Modified by: Casey M Holliday
